timeline.message: Merge branch 'main' of github.com:twilio/twilio-java into di-799-joda-time
Merge branch 'di-799-joda-time' of github.com:twilio/twilio-java into di-799-joda-time
Merge branch 'di-799-joda-time' of github.com:twilio/twilio-java into di-799-joda-time

timeline.bodyText: "Range" is not correct. Where is this coming from?
timeline.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: This was a mistake, should be "EndTime", will fix.
replies.author: thinkingserious

timeline.bodyText: This removes functionality where I could before provide a single EndTime rather than needing to provide both upper and lower bound on the end time.
timeline.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText:
You can still call addQueryParam as above; however, calling addQueryDateTimeRange should be transparent to the caller since if only endTime is defined, we achieve the same effect as calling addQueryParam.
Are you proposing that we create an additional function that sits on top of addQueryParam, something along the lines of addQueryEndDateTime? Or in these cases, just use addQueryParam as before?
replies.author: thinkingserious

replies.bodyText: No, I'm saying I used to be able to call setStartTime and it would add the query param StartTime=. Now it does EndTime>= I'm guessing?
replies.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: This is the current behavior when we just set the startTime and this example for setting just the endTime. And here is how we did it before.
replies.author: thinkingserious

replies.bodyText: Those are Request examples. I'm talking about the CallReader interface.
replies.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: Ah, how about replacing setStartTime() and setEndTime() with setAbsoluteStartTime(), setAbsoluteEndTime(), setRangeStartTime() and setRangeEndTime()?
replies.author: thinkingserious

replies.bodyText:
Why can't we use what all the other languages use? Examples: https://www.twilio.com/docs/sms/api/message-resource?code-sample=code-read-list-messages-filter-by-before-sent-date&code-language=Ruby&code-sdk-version=5.x
setStartTime, setStartTimeBefore, setStartTimeAfter.
replies.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText:
The biggest difference is that in other languages we can pass named parameters. In the closest implementation (C#), we have a builder that sorts the date/time stuff.
In the Java case, we can keep the building of the query params in addQueryParams and then add the variables startTime, startTimeBefore, startTimeAfter, endTimeBefore, endTime and endTimeAfter along with their getters & setters. How does that implementation sound?
replies.author: thinkingserious

replies.bodyText: That's fine. As long as users can still individually provide startTime, startTimeBefore, and startTimeAfter.
replies.author: childish-sambino

timeline.bodyText: This should nullify this.startTime, and setStartTime should nullify this.startTimeBefore/After.
timeline.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: Ah, same for the other methods too, correct? I'll add some tests to verify this functionality.
replies.author: thinkingserious

timeline.bodyText: What happened to these docs? They provide context for the difference between startTime and startTimeBefore, etc.
timeline.author: eshanholtz

replies.bodyText: They're up above on setStartTime. It doesn't really make sense on any of these methods specifically since it's talking about StartTime>=YYYY-MM-DD and the like.
replies.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: I think some clarification that the Before() maps to StartTime<=YYYY-MM-DD and After maps to StartTime>=YYYY-MM-DD would be helpful in these situations. Yes the docs say that you can specify the inequality, but they're not on the methods that actually allow you to use that functionality.
replies.author: eshanholtz

replies.bodyText: The doc string is coming from the api definition.
replies.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: Yeah, but we control the building of these additional functions. We can make the inequality setter builders render a clarifying function docstring ourselves that is independent of api-defs
replies.author: eshanholtz

replies.bodyText: I will be looking at these comments again after implementing the Yoyodyne changes to ensure they make sense in context.
replies.author: thinkingserious

timeline.bodyText: Why is this a LocalDate type when it previously had date_time precision?
timeline.author: eshanholtz

replies.bodyText:
Great catch! I'm going to double check all of these mappings. This particular one should be a ZonedDateTime.
Reference:
org.joda.time.DateTime ~> java.time.ZonedDateTime
org.joda.time.LocalDate ~> java.time.LocalDate
replies.author: thinkingserious

replies.bodyText: Are you making use of/updating the type mappings defined in api-defs? https://code.hq.twilio.com/twilio/api-definitions/blob/master/types/java.json
replies.author: eshanholtz

replies.bodyText:
Yes: https://code.hq.twilio.com/twilio/api-definitions/pull/2068/files
This will also be updated as part of this PR to remove the Range type.
replies.author: thinkingserious

timeline.message: Merge branch 'main' of github.com:twilio/twilio-java into remove-guava-range
Merge branch 'main' of github.com:twilio/twilio-java into remove-guava-range

timeline.bodyText: Lots of trivial whitespace changes cluttering up the PR should be removed (to files where there are no other changes).
timeline.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: Fixing these with the Yoyodyne generation.
replies.author: thinkingserious

replies.bodyText: Fixing these with the Yoyodyne generation.
replies.author: thinkingserious

timeline.bodyText: This should be in a separate PR.
timeline.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: Thought I caught that one ...
replies.author: thinkingserious

timeline.bodyText: Why is there no messageDate here? Was this not generated by yoyodyne?
timeline.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: This is a manual mistake, fixing.
replies.author: thinkingserious

timeline.author: childish-sambino

timeline.bodyText:
This is being called as request.addQueryDateTimeRange("StartTime", startTimeBefore, startTimeAfter);, but startTimeBefore is really an upper bound.
Given that this was able to pass without any tests breaking, tests need to be updated to catch this.
timeline.author: childish-sambino

replies.bodyText: Nice catch! Will fix.
replies.author: thinkingserious

timeline.message: fix date lower and upper bounds

timeline.bodyText: We don't do this in other languages. I'm against doing it here.
timeline.author: childish-sambino
